title: Simon Amstell webchat â as it happened | Stage | The Guardian
summary: `` i woke up wishing my hair was n't curly for many years ''
`` your identity is constructed from a combination of childhood trauma and the culture 's requirements of you ''
post your questions for simon amstell .

documents.title: that 's it for today
text: thanks very much to simon and to everyone who asked questions .
we hope you enjoyed this !
cheers
eugenie kang asks : love sucks .
it does n't happen for me .
well happened once but un-returned , non exchangeable nor refundable .
is it to do with self-loathing ?
if i somehow discover self love , will i be loved by other so called fellow human beings ?
guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 2:31pm yes .
you must love yourself .
the reasons you have for not loving yourself , you have made up .
interrogate these false allegations until the beauty of your true self emerges .
good luck .
you 're my favourite .

documents.title: `` i woke up wishing my hair was n't curly for many years ''
text: id6927857 asks : do you ever wake up and wish your hair was n't curly ?
guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 2:28pm i did for many years .
i wanted curtains like the boy who played joseph in a school production where i played pharoah .
he was beautiful , and vulnerable , and i was just curly .
dom payne says : i was in a band called grandma 's house years and years ago .
we considered threatening legal action when your show was aired , but decided against it when we realised the funny man off popworld was making it .
did you ever listen to us ?
edit : also , we used to be the top result on google until your show .
we were only young , and we were absolutely heartbroken .
guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 2:24pm i 'm so sorry .
i would like to hear the music of grandma 's house .
can you send me a cd please , if these things still exist ?
wolf kronos asks : hello simon , sometimes i used to watch television and sometimes you were on it and i thought you were funny .
laughing is important so thanks for the good times .
i fear for the future of our world , because lets be honest politicians are gross human beings generally .
do you fear the future , how do we remedy this ?
guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 2:23pm well , a tricky question .
i think it may be best to ignore politicians in the same way that you can avoid films or tv shows that do n't express something truthful about humanity .
and meditate , you must meditate .
good luck .
i love you .
royisgreat asks : do you own or rent your glasses ?
guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 2:20pm own .
danboy asks : hi simon , do you think the intellect works in opposition to love or can the two be combined ?
if love is the purpose of life , what is the purpose of intellect ?
guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 2:06pm you ca n't think your way to being in love , or able to be loved .
however , intellect is also useful for things like understanding books .
chris carter says : that 's a very attractive of you .
guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 2:05pm thank you chris carter .
your is very small , but i 'm sure it 's lovely .
id5708962 asks : you 're described here as the neurotic comedian yet you seem more the-opposite-of-neurotic than any other public figure i can think of .
this is because you 're able to be so refreshingly ( and humorously ) honest about your own humanness in all its messy oddity ( not just yours ) .
do you think the label is helpful , or would you rather be known as the wise well-balanced comedian ?
guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 2:04pm i ca n't believe the guardian have labelled me a `` neurotic '' comedian .
when clearly as you point out i am incredibly wise , and well-balanced .
i do n't know what to do about this .
what would you do ?
i suppose in the end , we all die , and these labels become as irrelevant as our lives .
andrew sigley asks : i went to one of your london gigs but outside after i was fearful and did n't say hello and instead kept looking over nervously .
instead i spent 5 minutes humorously telling my friends amusing anecdotes hoping you might hear and be impressed .
did you hear and were you impressed ?
guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 2:00pm yes .
you were brilliant .
i love you .
infinitedistraction asks : will you return the lighter you borrowed off of me in barfly in camden in 2007 please ?
guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 1:58pm i do n't think it was me .
peopleisstupid asks : i had a big crush on peter mills twenty-something years ago ( going so far as to paint my fingernails black to catch his eye in history ) did you too ?
guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 1:57pm mr mills was not just an excellent history teacher , but the director of all the school shows .
i did n't have a crush on him but i was very grateful for him giving me the roles of seymour in little shop of horrors , and fagin in oliver , even though i could n't really sing all the notes .
shlongfacedmutant asks : how did your family react to grandma 's house ?
and are there any plans for another series or perhaps some other television projects ?
guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 1:55pm the people who are generally full of joy and liked laughing seemed to like it very much .
my mum liked it the most i think .
and my grandma came to a screening of the pilot before she died , and really loved it .
justask asks : what is the secret to eternal youth ?
no prevarication , please .
also , what 's your favourite nut ?
guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 1:53pm be a vegan .
jump a lot .
brazil .

sul asks : do you agree with ade edmonson who said recently that standup is an inherently flawed art form having the limitation of having to make people laugh every minute or so being an unnecessary and tedious restriction on a performance .
stewart lee , paul foot and others are prepared to risk audience silence for achingly long periods .
are you ?

guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 1:51pm i understand why the need to make people laugh may seem limiting , but i feel more free on stage than i do just about anywhere else as i 'm able to say things i ca n't say in any other context .
and to me what is funny is usually the most truthful thing , so if the limitation is that you have to be truthful then i 'm pretty happy with that .
veganlifeassoc asks : hi simon , we understand that you 're vegan ?
please can you tell us more about why veganism is important to you ?
( oh and what 's you 're favourite vegan meal ? ! )
vegan lifestyle assocation .
guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 1:49pm hello , the vegan lifestyle association .
how wonderful to speak with you today .
i saw the documentary earthlings , and it felt like in the future we will look at what we do to animals now with the same horror that we now look at slavery or the holocaust .
happy christmas !
favourite meal : vegan chocolate cake .
johnnytextface asks : i saw you in bath once , i put my arm around you for a photograph .
you immediately placed your hand on my back but then slowly moved it away like you did n't want to touch me .
did you not want to touch me ?
guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 1:45pm i ca n't remember .
perhaps i was in a rush ?
i think i 'll be in bath for this tour if you 'd like me to touch you for slightly longer .
sorry .
cara shanley says : hello simon , i hope you 're having a good day .
: ) guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 1:44pm thank you , i am .
cameron ferguson asks : how do you stay grounded in the present moment , and do you allow guilt from the past and fear of the future to cloud your mind ?
guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 1:42pm i do n't think i have too much guilt , and try to avoid fear about the future because it 's all too distracting , and depressing .
i stay grounded in the present moment by either creating something when i 'm on my own , or looking directly into the eyes of the person i 'm with and knowing everything is fine .
until they start to feel that i 'm staring at them .
snukin asks : hello simon .
what is your favourite vegetable ?
also , do you ever feel overwhelmed by the vastness of the universe ?
guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 1:40pm aubergine .
and yes .
missrobertson asks : who is the inspiration for the auntie liz character on grandma 's house ?
guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 1:39pm she 's not based on one particular person , but more a kind of attitude .

she 's the sort of person who does think other people are weird and ca n't accept anything different to the life she 's living because it would destroy the illusion that she 's living the best possible life .
everything , then , is a threat ; she feels constantly under attack by the things and people occurring in the world that are slightly more fascinating than her .
lifeon asks : when i saw you performing numb it really made me feel a little less weird about being me .
it was incredibly cathartic and refreshing , unlike anyone else i 'd seen .
do you feel that everyone is a bit weird and has these neuroses underneath , or do they just belong to a lucky anxious few ?
is normal a thing ?
guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 1:38pm normal is invented .
the word 'weird ' is invented , and used by people who are scared of who they are .
a french psychologist i met once at some sort of buddhist retreat said that the idea that we 're each special is a trick of the ego - we are absolutely all completely unique .
shannon theresa maxwell asks : what is the inspiration behind the name of your new tour ?

guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 1:36pm the way i write a new show is i go and talk in front of a small room of people who have paid very little money , for over an hour about whatever i 'm curious or frustrated about , or feeling ashamed of at the time , and it turned out that everything i was talking about seems to be connected to a sense of my freedom being restricted in some way .
that i wanted to be at an orgy but something in my personality would n't allow this to happen .
that i wanted to be able to heal somebody of their depression at a party but i was somehow not free to do that either .
and i thought to be free had a feeling of optimism to it while not being too final .
i 'm hoping that it gives the impression that i 'm on some sort of journey towards freedom , and that i have n't become a complete lunatic .
idiamin asks : hi simon , do you ever actually wash your hair or is this what happens when you let it self-clean ?
guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 1:32pm i do wash my hair .
i 'm not sure what you mean when you say , `` is this what happens '' .

documents.title: `` your identity is constructed from a combination of childhood trauma and the culture 's requirements of you ''
text: parkshark asks : do you think your identity can change so completely as to demarcate your life into clear stages ( e.g .
paranoid - > free ) or do you think your identity takes on a more constant shape early on and you just grapple with your formed tendencies in different ways as you age ?
that is , judging by descriptions of your new material , you 've seemed to have graduated from the stage in your life of over-analyzing and over-worrying .
as someone in the thick of that stage , i was wondering if you feel you can , with time and experience , truly leave such tendencies behind you and move on .

( big love from chicago and seoul ) guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 1:31pm i think your identity can change because i think it 's mainly something that is constructed from a combination of childhood trauma and the culture 's requirements of you .
i see myself changing over the various standup shows that i 've done .

the previous two standup shows , numb and do nothing , were both quite focused on my horrific loneliness whereas this new one to be free seems to be about finding a kind of inner joy that has led me to now desire complete freedom beyond any insecurity of my own , or the culture 's .
however , i think it 's very easy to fall back into old patterns unless you maintain some kind of ritualistic practice , like meditation , or jumping around every morning to michael jackson songs .
matthewlumby asks : you 've been on the late show twice now .
david letterman must like you to invite you back , but did he say anything to you or offer any tips on comedy ?
guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 1:28pm hello .
thank you for your question .
i 'm not sure if letterman is involved in any of the bookings .
however , i think being invited back means he definitely does n't hate me .
there were no tips on comedy , he did shake my hand and say well done , but then he walked away .

documents.title: simon is now with us !
text: here is proof : beaumont-thomas guardian contributor simonamstell1 03 december 2014 1:26pm testing , testing

documents.title: post your questions for simon amstell
text: to many people simon amstell will seem like the very of success , having created a series of well-liked tv shows , done standup appearances in the us , and grown fabulously curly hair .
but the success always belied and occasionally induced neuroses that meant he was apparently doomed to social awkwardness .
whether it was holidaying alone and finding himself to be a horny sex pest , or refusing cocaine on the grounds he 'd just eaten , amstell was trapped in a prison of his own making .
but now , in new standup show to be free , he 's broken out .
finding himself to be happier than ever , he is taking on society 's ills rather than his own .
in a four-star guardian review , brian logan wrote that it was a constantly delightful and insightful tour of amstell 's responses to the world .
with amstell about to take the show on a nationwide tour , he 's joining us to answer your questions in a live webchat , from 1pm gmt onwards on wednesday 3 december .
post yours in the comments below , and he 'll try to answer as many as possible .

bulletin.text: Why is he so self-loathing? How does he style his hair? And what did his grandma think of Grandma's House? Read the comedian's answers to your questions now.
